slide.paragraphs: Given a continuous function over a closed interval. We want to approximate the area of the region bounded by the graph of the function and the $x$-axis.
One way to do so is by viewing the region roughly as a union of sequence of rectangles, and then adding up the areas of these rectangles.

collapse.paragraphs: Intuitively, we see that the more (and smaller) rectangles are used, the more closely their union approximates the region in question.

statement.paragraphs: Let $f : [a, b] \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a continuous function on a closed interval. The

$\displaystyle \int_a^b f(x)\,dx$ of $f$ over $[a, b]$ is equal to the limit as $n$ tends to infinity of the left Riemann sum defined previously. That is: \[ \begin{split} \int_a^b f(x)\, dx &= \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} LS_n(f)\\ &= \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{b - a}{n}\,\sum_{k = 0}^{n -1} f\left(a + \frac{k(b - a)}{n}\right) \end{split} \]

slide.paragraphs: It is an established theorem that the limit exists if $f$ is continuous.
(In fact: One could define the definite integral in terms of the Right Riemann Sum or the Midpoint Riemann Sum. All these sums tend to same limit in the case where $f$ is continuous.)
Our eventual goal is to show that if $F$ is an antiderivative of a continuous function $f$, then: \[ \int_a^b f(x)\,dx = F(x)\bigg|_a^b := F(b) - F(a). \]

newcol.paragraphs: \[ \int_a^b f(u(x))u'(x)\,dx = \int_{u(a)}^{u(b)} f(u)\,du = F(u(b)) - F(u(a)) \] if $F$ is an antiderivative of $f$.
Before we prove the main theorem, we first state a couple of preliminary results.

statement.paragraphs: For a continuous function $f$ on $[a, b]$, we define: \[ \int_a^a f(x)\,dx = 0. \] \[ \int_b^a f(x)\,dx = -\int_a^b f(x)\,dx. \]
Let $f$ be a continuous function on an interval $I$. For all $a, b, c \in I$, we have: \[ \int_a^b f(x)\,dx + \int_b^c f(x)\,dx = \int_a^c f(x)\,dx. \]
Let $f, g$ be continuous functions on $[a, b]$. If $f(x) \leq g(x)$ for all $x \in [a, b]$, then: \[ \int_a^b f(x)\,dx \leq \int_a^b g(x)\,dx. \]

statement.paragraphs: Find the area of the region in the $xy$-plane bounded between the graph of $y = x^2 - 2x - 3$ and the $x$-axis over the interval $[1, 5]$.

newcol.paragraphs: The geometric area of the region described is equal to: \[ \int_1^5 \abs{x^2 - 2x - 3} \,dx \] Consider the sign chart for the values of $f(x) = x^2 - 2x - 3 = (x + 1)(x - 3)$ over the interval $[1, 5]$:

$\displaystyle \int_1^5 \abs{x^2 - 2x - 3} \,dx$ \[ \begin{split} &= \int_1^3 \abs{x^2 - 2x - 3} \, dx + \int_3^5 \abs{x^2 - 2x - 3} \, dx\\ &= \int_1^3 -\left( x^2 - 2x - 3 \right) \, dx + \int_3^5 \left( x^2 - 2x - 3 \right) \, dx\\ &= -\left.\left( \frac{1}{3}x^3 - x^2 - 3x \right) \right|_1^3 + \left.\left( \frac{1}{3}x^3 - x^2 - 3x \right)\right|_3^5\\ &= \frac{16}{3} + \frac{32}{3}\\ &= 16 \end{split} \]

statement.paragraphs: Let $f$ be a continuous function on $[a, b]$. Define a function $F : [a, b] \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}$ as follows: \[ F(x) = \int_a^x f(t)\,dt, \quad x \in [a, b]. \] Then, $F$ is continuous on $[a, b]$ and differentiable on $(a, b)$, with: \[ F'(x) = f(x) \] for all $x \in (a, b)$. Equivalently:

newcol.paragraphs: By definition: \[ \begin{split} F'(x) &= \lim_{h \rightarrow 0}\frac{F(x + h) - F(x)}{h}.\\ & = \lim_{h \rightarrow 0}\frac{\int_a^{x + h}f(t)\,dt - \int_a^xf(t)\,dt}{h}.\\ & = \lim_{h \rightarrow 0}\frac{\int_x^{x + h}f(t)\,dt}{h}. \end{split} \]

collapse.paragraphs: By the Mean Value Theorem for Integrals, there exists $c_h \in [x, x + h]$ such that: \[ f(c_h) = \frac{\int_x^{x + h}f(t)\,dt}{h}. \] Hence:
\[ F'(x) = \lim_{h \rightarrow 0}f(c_h) = f(x), \] since for any $h$ the number $c_h$ lies between $x$ and $x + h$, and $f$ is continuous.
We leave the proof of the continuity of $F$ on $[a, b]$ as an exercise.

statement.title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part II
Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part II
statement.paragraphs: Let $f$ be a continuous function on $[a, b]$. Let $F$ be a continuous function on $[a, b]$ which is an antiderivative of $f$ over $(a, b)$. Then: \[ \int_a^b f(x)\,dx = F(b) - F(a). \]

newcol.paragraphs: By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part I, we know that $G(x) = \int_a^x f(t)\,dt$ is also an antiderivative of $f$. By Lagrange's Mean Value Theorem and the continuity of $F$ and $G$ on $[a, b]$, for all $x \in [a, b]$ we have: \[ G(x) = F(x) + C \] for some constant $C$.

collapse.paragraphs: Hence: \[ \int_a^b f(t)\,dt = G(b) = F(b) + C = F(b) - F(a). \]
